response.answer_text: Actually only Pakistani Erdogan fanboys hate on Atatürk. Because Erdogan hates secularism. Arabs primarily hate on the Ottoman Empire, claiming that the Ottomans turned the Arabian peninsula into an Ottoman colony. Even Assad recently claimed that the Turkish army being in Syria is basically Erdogan rebuilding the Ottoman Empire. The hatred towards Atatürk within Turkey primarily stems from the 1980s coup. Where the Turkish military tried to force people to “like” Atatürk. Which as you can see didn’t work. Most of this hatred however is based on fiction rather than facts. The general who took over Turkey also did other things that made the Islamists hate him, like banning the headscarf in public institutions. Since most Islamists in Turkey are uneducated, they think that this ban was put there by Atatürk. Not realizing that even Atatürk’s wife had a headscarf. Atatürk never forbade the headscarf. The Islamists in Turkey literally came up with an alternative history to justify their hatred. Like claiming that Atatürk was born in Malatya instead of Selanik (Thessaloniki). Claiming that his mother was a prostitute, which she wasn’t. Claiming that his father was unknown, even though his father is known (his father is Ali Rıza Efendi). Claiming that the Treaty of Lausanne wasn’t that good. And they’ve came up with a lot more ridiculous bullshit to justify their hate. They even claim that ghosts/jinns (genies) protected Turkey during the Gallipoli Campaign, because the Turks were super religious, instead of giving Atatürk credit for his military strategies. On top of that the Turkish population was superstitious back then not super religious, mainly because they couldn’t read or write. And their religion was primarily based on what they were told, not what they read if they could read. Within the last 100 years much hasn’t changed though. There are even pseudo-historians in Turkey who are worshipped by Islamists for all their false claims. And Erdogan was good friends with one of them who recently died. That guy was declared insane and treated in a clinic a couple of decades ago. He said, “I wished the Greeks had won Turkey’s war of independence”. Erdogan hates Atatürk so much, that in history lessons about Turkey’s war of independence, the name Atatürk is removed. That is like removing Napoleon’s name from the Napoleonic Wars. And Erdogan’s picture is placed in places where you previously only had Atatürk’s picture. On top of that at some places Atatürk’s paintings were deliberately removed like at the Turkish parliament without an explanation. You can compare Erdogan’s hatred towards Atatürk to Trump’s hatred towards Obama. The only difference is, Atatürk died 17 years before Erdogan was even born. You can compare this hatred with an American president hating and comparing himself to the Fouding Fathers. Can you even imagine how ridiculous that is? Historically however Atatürk did inspire leaders in the Middle East to also have an independent and modern nation, instead of being a puppet state runned by French and British imperialists. For example, Gamal Abdel Nasser from Egypt. One of the thing she did was nationalising the Suez Canal. Reza Shah from Iran was also inspired by Atatürk, trying to modernize and secularize his country like Atatürk. But he faced a lot more internal resistance from Islamists. Atatürk is also respected in Azerbaijan, Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus and Turkic countries in Central Asia (like Kazakhstan).

Well, this is among ultra conservative Turks, conservative Sunnis from places like Jordan, Palestine, Syria, Iraq, Pakistan. They believe that fault him for dissolving the Ottoman Empire and founding a republic and then he got rid of the Ottoman script, which was modeled after the Perso-Arabic script, and replaced it with Latin. Many conservative Muslims, including some Turks, believe it was done to distance the people of the new republic from the Arabs and others who were formerly part of the Ottoman Empire and align Turkey more with the West. Anyway, what Ataturk intended to do has partially succeeded, but not completely as we can see from the current leadership in Turkey. However, that leadership is having a difficult time because of decades of Ataturk type programs have changed Turkish culture and heavily aligned Turkey economically and culturally to the West, and going far from that is causing havoc with Turkey’s economy. Also, secular Turks cherish personal freedoms and are often irreligious and openly so, but one cannot do that in Arab world. They don’t want to be associated with the conservatism of the Arab world and don’t want to see their country become increasingly conservative and, as I said, they associate conservative ways with the Arab world and Middle East, but conservative Muslims don’t think that way. They believe Turks should rightfully to take up the mantle of Islam again like in the days of the Caliphate and that Ataturk took the Turks away from that. Anyway, I explained why some Muslims think that way. I don’t think there is any need to insult people whether Arabs or Turks or any figures. I think people should try to be respectful.
